page.title: 06BEEF FARMING IN EAST SUSSEX
page.content: A TYPICAL BEEF FARM IN OUR AREA COVERS 40 TO 55 HECTARES AND HAS 35 TO 40 CATTLE. THE MAIN MEAT PRODUCING BREEDS ARE CROSSES BETWEEN FRISIANS,HEREFORDS AND CHAROLAIS.IN ADDITION, 6 TO 8 MILKING COWS, SUCH AS JERSEYS, ARE KEPT TO FEED THE CALVES. SOME FARMERS ALSO FEED THE CALVES ON BUCKETS OF POWDERED MILK. THE CALVES ARE BOUGHT FROM DAIRY FARMERS AT ABOUT 2 WEEKS OLD AND ARE KEPT INDOORS FOR THE FIRST 3 TO 4 MONTHS BEFORE BEING PUT OUT TO GRAZE. IN THE SUMMER THE MILK COWS HAVE TO BE BROUGHT IN EARLY IN THE MORNING TO FEED THE CALVES.THE CALVES ARE SOLD FOR SLAUGHTER AT THE AGE OF 10 TO 12 MONTHS AT HAYWARDS HEATH AND OTHER NEARBY MARKETS. OTHER SUMMER TASKS INCLUDE THE CUTTING OF YOUNG GRASS FOR SILAGE WHICH IS DONE BY CONTRACTORS. OTHER FODDER CROPS PRODUCED INCLUDE HAY AND KALE.
